awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Protein evolution in high-dimensional sequence space
awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins are molecular machines that living things use to eat, grow, and reproduce; they evolve over time and yet we have no tools to predict their adaptation to novel environments.  Protein evolution is key to how germs become resistant to drugs, for example.  As another example, engineers can apply the evolution of new protein functions to help break down oil spills.  Predicting these adaptive changes in advance would greatly enhance our understanding of adaptation but would also open the door for new biological tools to confront environmental challenges.  This project will develop computational tools to help scientists both predict and understand how proteins evolve.  To do so, the researchers are experimentally studying the evolution of brightly colored proteins isolated from coral.  They are then using the information from these experimental studies to develop general computational models to understand and predict protein evolution.  Such tools will be powerful, enabling both more effective protein engineering and intervention in the evolution of undesired features such as drug-resistance.  Finally, the project is designed to provide opportunities for high school STEM teachers in Oregon to directly participate in the research. Teacher research experiences demonstrably improve educational outcomes in STEM classrooms. 

As an experimental model for protein evolution, the researchers are studying a collection of possible evolutionary trajectories between an ancestral and modern green fluorescent protein (GFP)-like protein from a coral in the genus Favia. The ancestral protein was green; the modern protein is red.  This phenotypic change was achieved through 15 historical substitutions. The researchers are constructing all combinations of these mutations and characterizing the fluorescence of each genotype.  This will allow them to map the collection of possible trajectories connecting the starting and end states. In parallel, they are developing computational tools to dissect epistasis, to describe connectivity, and to predict unmeasured phenotypes.  This work will provide: 1) A publicly available, high-dimensional genotype-phenotype map covering the evolution of a new protein function; 2) Powerful software for studies of evolutionary trajectories; and 3) Deep insight into the determinants of protein evolutionary trajectories in high-dimensional genotype-phenotype maps.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was centered on understanding how proteins evolve new functions. Over the term of this award, we learned about mechanisms of protein evolution, developed software to try to predict protein evolution, trained multiple PhD and undergraduate students, and provided continuing education/curriculum development opportunities for high school teachers from under-served rural school districts. 

Proteins are the molecular machines that do the jobs cells need to live. Among many roles, proteins break down food, help cells move, and give cells their structures. Each protein is built out of a chain of amino acids (think beads on a string). Different amino acids have different molecular properties, so changing the identities of the amino acids in the chain can alter how the protein does its job. 

Proteins evolve when copying errors lead to changes in amino acid sequence (mutations). Although scientists are reasonably good at understanding how one mutation alters a protein, it becomes hard to predict what happens when multiple mutations occur. This is because one mutation might interact with another mutation and thus change its effects. Most protein function evolves through five or more mutations, so these interactions between mutations make predicting functional change is nearly impossible. 

If we could predict the evolution of new protein function, we could build drugs that are difficult for germs to evolve to escape. We will also be able to engineer proteins to do new functions, improving manufacturing and other processes that rely on proteins. 

We made important progress towards understanding the evolution of protein function. We published five papers that investigated different aspects of protein evolution. The most important work consisted of insights into how to understand the combined effects of mutations. How, mechanistically, does one mutation change the effect of another mutation? Once we understand the mechanism, can we build a computational tool to predict interactions? 

We identified a mechanism for interactions between mutations that is likely common but had been missed in previous studies of protein evolution. This mechanism occurs because proteins flip between multiple shapes as part of their function. Imagine your hand opening and closing. Something analogous happens for proteins, where they move between different shapes. Our insight was that a single mutation could have a different effect on each shape. In the hand analogy, this would be equivalent to painting your fingernails: the paint is visible when your palm is open, but invisible when you clench your fit. The paint (a mutation) affects one shape (open) but not the other (closed). 

This effect can lead to interesting interactions between mutations in proteins. Two mutations, each introduced alone, might have no effect at all. Maybe they each alter different shapes. But if you introduce the mutations together, they suddenly have an effect because both shapes have been altered at once. We wrote out simple physics-based models describing these effects and found we could get interactions between dozens of mutations with this insight. We also found we could reproduce this result experimentally. 

Besides describing this effect, we wrote open-source software that anyone can use to predict the combined effects of mutations. The algorithm was based on the insights we gained from our experimental and mathematical work on this mechanism of interactions between mutations. 

This work also provided a fertile ground for training new researchers. Three different PhD students participated in this project, learning valuable skills that they have taken into the scientific workforce. (One is a software engineer, one is a professor, and one is a researcher at a biotech company). Two undergraduate students also received training during this project. Both have joined PhD programs and are continuing to develop as biological scientists. 

Finally, we brought two high school teachers into the lab to do summer research projects. They contributed directly to the scientific projects, learning new lab skills. We also worked with them to develop curriculum to teach principles of protein evolution using some cool, glowing proteins from coral. They deployed these lessons in their classroom and created a kit that other teachers can use for hands-on protein evolution education. 

The work started in this project is ongoing. This award helped launch a new research direction in the Harms lab. As we continue to pursue these mechanisms of epistasis, we hope to build general tools that allow researchers around the world to predict the evolution of new protein functions.
